sen.j: 桓武天皇・嵯峨天皇に厚い信任を得ながら、俗事を嫌い三輪山の麓に隠棲したという玄賓（げんぴん）僧都の庵と伝えられる。
sen.e: The legend of the temple says that this was originally a hermitage of Genpin, who didn't like earthy affairs and moved to the foot of the mountain called Miwa, despite he was trusted greatly by the Emperor Kanmu and the Emperor Saga.

sen.j: かつては山岳仏教の寺として三輪山の檜原谷にあったが、明治初年の神仏分離により現在地に移された。
sen.e: The temple once was in the valley of Hibara of Mt. Miwa and performed as a temple of Mountain Buddhism, but moved down to the current place when the Meiji government issued the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism at the very beginning of the Meiji period.
